summary: The document examines the transcription of a tape from 11 June 1962, relevant to the President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act, highlighting the role of professional transcribers and native Russian speakers in correcting previous inaccuracies. It clarifies that Nosenko did not claim to have been in the United States and that the alias Nikolayev was used in England and the Soviet Union, not the United States. This underscores the critical need for precise transcription in intelligence contexts to avoid misinterpretation.
key_findings: Professional transcribers corrected discrepancies in previous transcriptions of the tape.
New transcriptions by native Russian speakers found no evidence of Nosenko claiming to have been in the United States.
The alias Nikolayev was clarified to have been used in England and the Soviet Union, not the United States.
The document highlights the importance of accurate transcription and the risks of misinterpretation in intelligence work.
keywords: President John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Act
